title: Ticket #7511: Master-started daemons' socket names don't need a sequence number
description:
If the master ensures the uniqueness of the socket names of its direct children, it can dispense with the sequence number in the shared port socket ID. This would make it possible to contact a daemon's sibling by changing the subsys/local name portion of the shared port ID.

Possibly depending on the host OS, it may also be possible to remove the arbitrary integer suffix as well, which would make the major shared port socket IDs more compact. (Major meaning, "those started directly by the master." Other shared port listeners may not have unique base socket IDs; starters, for instance, certainly don't, and sockets created by tools probably don't.)
